raw_text:
Wales 'must learn health lessons'
 
 The new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists.
 
 Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile Ms Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.
 
 In November the British Medical Association said NHS staff were "weeping with despair" as figures showed 311,000 people were waiting for treatment in Wales, up by 2,400 on the previous month. In the same month lists in England were at their lowest for 17 years, with 856,600 people waiting for treatment. Dr Gibbons told Radio Wales: "There is no doubt that, in managing waiting lists, England has done a lot of very very useful work, and we do need to learn from that."
 
 But he said the NHS in Wales also needed to create a healthier population rather than respond only to ill health, and a balanced view of priorities was important. "We do need a consistent across-the-board approach, recognising the patients' experience of how they use the service is going to be, at the end of the day, the main test of how the service is working." He said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". Later, Dr Gibbons praised the work of Ms Hutt, saying he "agreed with everything she's done" to change the health service in Wales. Dr Gibbons said he accepted there was a problem, but his job now was to build on the foundations put in place by his predecessor. He also acknowledged that until the waiting list issue was sorted out, the rest of the assembly government's health policy would be overshadowed.
 
 Opposition members and some Labour MPs had long called for Ms Hutt's removal after sustained criticism over extended hospital waiting times. First Minister Rhodri Morgan told BBC Wales he had agreed with Ms Hutt in 2003 that she would not be health minister in the run-up to the 2007 elections. "She's been doing the job for five years and eight months and, apart from Nye Bevan himself, (architect of the NHS), I don't think anybody has ever done the job for so long." Mr Morgan said he had only told Ms Hutt of the reshuffle on Monday morning, and said the NHS in Wales was Dr Gibbons' "baby" now. In response to Dr Gibbons' comments, Ieuan Wyn Jones, leader of the Plaid Cymru group in the assembly, said: "It is apparent that this reshuffle by the first minister was just changing the deckchairs on a sinking Titanic." Kisrty Williams, for the Lib Dems, added: "If the underlying policy is going to continue, then changing the minister will serve no purpose, other than to deflect flak from Labour's MPs," she said. Meanwhile Ms Hutt said she hoped "that the people of Wales would benefit from my investment of the past five years and eight months" Asked about waiting lists, she said that waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda" and that the Welsh Assembly Government had "turned the corner" on the issue.
llama3.2:1b: Wales' new health minister Dr Brian Gibbons says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists.
He admits the NHS in Wales is facing challenges but insists essential services are in place.
The British Medical Association reported 311,000 people waiting for treatment in Wales, up 2,400 on previous month.
Dr Gibbons praises Ms Hutt's work on the health service and says a balanced view of priorities is important.
However, opposition members say the issue needs to be addressed before policy can shift focus from addressing waiting times.
The new minister has acknowledged the problem but wants to build on what was done by his predecessor Jane Hutt.
llama3.2:3b: Wales' new health minister Dr Brian Gibbons says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists, but also emphasizes the need for a balanced approach and creating a healthier population.
He praised his predecessor Jane Hutt's record, despite criticism over extended hospital waiting times.
The opposition parties, including Plaid Cymru and Liberal Democrats, have called for policy changes, while First Minister Rhodri Morgan has defended Ms Hutt's long tenure as health minister.
gemma2:2b: Dr Brian Gibbons, new Wales health minister, acknowledges challenges with waiting lists but believes the NHS is in a good place to address them.

He emphasizes the need for learning from England's successful strategies while highlighting the importance of creating a healthier population and ensuring patient experience remains at the forefront of service evaluation.
The Welsh assembly government has acknowledged the problem with extended hospital waiting times, leading to Ms Hutt's dismissal after five years in the post.
Opposition figures criticize this change, arguing it is merely changing the deckchairs on a sinking ship.
Despite this, Dr Gibbons expresses confidence in building upon the foundations laid by Ms Hutt and promises to tackle waiting lists effectively.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The new Welsh Health Minister needs to learn from England’s experience in tackling waiting lists.
Dr Brian Gibbons acknowledges that NHS staff are facing a challenging situation, but argues they have developed essential skills.
He believes Wales must create a healthier population and prioritize both physical and mental health.
However, he notes that the assembly government has shifted its priorities since Mr Hutt took office, and the Welsh Assembly Government will continue to take responsibility for healthcare delivery.
The Health Minister hopes that her work on waiting lists benefits the population of Wales.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Wales must learn from England's improvements in managing NHS waitlists after new health minister Dr Brian Gibbons takes office following Jane Hutt's removal.
Issues like long waiting times for treatment are now a top priority, as Wales seeks to replicate England's strategies despite different local conditions.

The Welsh government aims to create a healthier population and maintain a balanced approach while building on the foundations laid by former AM Jane Hutt during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as health minister.
qwen2.5:3b: Wales's new health minister Dr Brian Gibbons acknowledges challenges in tackling long NHS waiting lists, admitting there are lessons to be learned from England’s management.
Both Plaid Cymru and Liberal Democrats criticized his approach despite his assurance that essential policies were in place.
Hutt defended her record by emphasizing the importance of preventive healthcare over immediate treatment issues, which accounted for only 10% of health priorities.
Gibbons praised Hutt's work but emphasized he needs to consolidate the NHS after recent reforms.
Welsh MPs and opposition parties criticized Hutt’s leadership, with some suggesting she should have been replaced earlier.
Despite criticism, Hutt maintained that progress had been made on waiting lists and hoped for benefits from her tenure.
opencoder:1.5b: The new health minister for Wales is learning from lessons in managing waiting lists.
Dr Gibbons, on his first full day, confronted the difficulties but insisted the essentials were in place to change policy.
Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record as it was "only 10% of the health agenda".
The England side agreed to create a healthier population rather than responding only to ill health and a balanced view of priorities is essential.

Dr Gibbons praised the work of Mr Hutt who also acknowledged that until the waiting list issue was sorted out, the rest of the assembly government's health policy would be overshadowed by his predecessor's work.

Both the Welsh government and parties oppose his changes, calling for a healthier population and balanced priorities.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Dr. Brian Gibbons, the new health minister for Wales, acknowledged significant challenges in managing NHS waiting lists but emphasized the necessity of learning from England's successful approaches to reduce these lists.
He praised the work of his predecessor, Jane Hutt, who served five years and eight months, stating that the NHS in Wales was her "baby."
Dr. Gibbons also highlighted the importance of addressing population health rather than solely focusing on illness and maintaining a consistent approach to patient care.

Opposition parties, including Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, criticized the reshuffle, with Plaid Cymru's leader, Ieuan Wyn Jones, likening it to "changing the deckchairs on a sinking Titanic."
Dr. Gibbons agreed that the waiting list issue was critical, and he pledged to build upon Hutt's efforts.
In contrast, Ms. Hutt defended her record, asserting that addressing waiting times and lists represented only 10% of Wales' health agenda.
She hoped the people of Wales would benefit from her five years and eight months of service.
The British Medical Association reported in November that 311,000 individuals were awaiting treatment in Wales, up by 2,400 from the previous month.
In comparison, England's waiting lists had reached their lowest point in 17 years with 856,600 people on the waitlist.
